s.text: Slate BiasServer TM applies this concept to the magazine world: You'll register your views just once, and Slate will thereafter recognize your browser and serve up opinion and analysis that reconfirm your prejudices.

(It will be posted Wednesday evening, Aug. 6.) Slate readers, of course, are much too morally austere to have any genuine interest in the sex lives of Hollywood stars, the diets of talk show hosts, and suchlike paranormal phenomena.
And don't forget the other ways Slate can come to you, instead of your having to come to us.
And don't forget the other ways Slate can come to you, instead of your having to come to us.
And don't forget the other ways Slate can come to you, instead of your having to come to us.
And don't forget the other ways Slate can come to you, instead of your having to come to us.
And don't forget the other ways Slate can come to you, instead of your having to come to us.
There's an easy e-mail sign-up form at the top of Today's Papers.
Getting your Slate this way is as easy as dismantling a medium-sized nuclear power plant.

Our "Summary Judgment" department, which saves you the trouble of reading reviews, will be upgraded into a service that will implant the consensus opinion on all the new movies, books, television shows, etc., directly into your brain, saving you the trouble of reading and seeing the books and shows themselves.
